title: Memoir of James Wyld of Gilston, and his family
snippet: This, since I prefer the fine air of the dining-room and my old writing desk bought when I was at College, I have handed over, key and all, to my wife, where she can shut herself up, elaborate her accounts, and write her letters, and no one may at such times intrude ; altogether, I know no house in Edinburgh which, for peace and convenience, I would prefer to my own house in Inverleith Row. We have, I may mention, during the last year (1888), got a funicular tramway, on which a system of superior carriages are constantly passing up and down from the Queensferry Road to Princes Street, so that at any moment we may run to Edinburgh, even on the most trifling mission, and be back within the half hour, and at a cost of twopence. We have thus the advantage  both of town and country life.

title: Memoir of James Wyld of Gilston, and his family
snippet: George Millar is dated 15th May of that year. Bonnington Bank lay about half a mile west from Leith, on the Queensferry Road. It consisted of a good house with two unfinished  wings, and two Scotch acres of land.
